title: Football news: Gareth Bale will play with emotion when Wales take on Slovakia in Euro 2020 qualifier
text:
Gareth Bale aims to use the 'anger' he has felt this season to drive Wales towards Euro 2020 qualification against Slovakia on Thursday.

The Real Madrid star appeared to be heading for the exit in the summer — with a £1million a week contract with Chinese club Jiangsu Suning on the table — after his relationship with coach Zinedine Zidane hit rock bottom.

But the move did not happen and Bale stayed to help Madrid climb to the top of La Liga, though he has rarely looked happy while doing so.

Gareth Bale aims to use the 'anger' he has felt this season when Wales face Slovakia

'You play with a lot of emotion [and] anger comes into it,' said Bale, who scored his first international goal against Slovakia in 2006. 'I try to enjoy it and give my best whether it's with Wales or Madrid.

'There is nothing to clear my mind about. I love meeting up with Wales, and we have a task at hand to try to qualify for the Euros.'

Bale did not feature in Real's disappointing Champions League draw with Club Brugge last week but returned for the league victory over Granada last weekend.

Coach Ryan Giggs said: 'I was surprised with what happened in the summer - I think everyone from the outside thought it was a bit strange. But it seems like everything on that has gone a bit quiet now.

He has helped Real Madrid to the top of the La Liga table but has rarely looked happy doing so

'Of course, it would have unsettled him because it was apparently very close for him going. But things might have changed. Things do change quite quickly in football and now he's playing, he's loved, he's happy, and I expect him to carry on doing what he's doing for Real Madrid.'

Giggs is again without Aaron Ramsey, who has not featured at all in qualifying, for a game where Wales have little margin for error if they want to keep alive their hopes of automatic qualification.

The Juventus midfielder has a thigh problem but did some light training on Wednesday and Wales hope he may be involved against Croatia on Sunday.

There are also injury doubts over forwards Harry Wilson and Tom Lawrence. Giggs insisted Lawrence is in the right frame of mind to play, with the Derby forward scheduled to appear before magistrates on October 15 after he was charged with drink-driving.

authors: Tom Collomosse For The Daily Mail
